reviewText:
Ever since my daughter was 3 years old we came across a game series called Putt-Putt... its a point and click adventure with basic logic problems. Your child only need be familiar with the very basics of using a mouse. There is nothing in it that a parent would disapprove of. If you're looking for a game for your child that doesn't have hitting or violence of any kind...this is the game...or game series.

My daughter is 6 now and still loves it...even though she is tearing through it much faster :)

Cheers
voteText: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText: I can already tell that this game is beautifully written and has one of the most intriguing plots of video game history. Putt-Putt®: Pep's Birthday Surprise shows the story of a post-apocalyptic wasteland where humans have mutated with vehicals and the struggles/importance of keeping up morale in a world where survival is easier said than done. This is shown through the Pep, the main character's trusty prisoner who has been kidnapped and abused all his life, and his journey to find a reason to continue living. The objective is to keep Pep from killing himself by throwing him a party, which is a unique plot device for an indie project such as this. When people say video games can't be art, I show them Putt-Putt®: Pep's Birthday Surprise.

reviewText: Point and click adventure game, perfect for young kids. I got my money out of it with how many times my kids have played it.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is the worst Putt-Putt game (although it's not completely awful). It just lacks the imaginative environments and characters of the previous games so it's not very exciting. The animation is worse than the other games and the voice actor changed again (worst one yet!). There is less gameplay and lengthier animated scenes, which isn't helped by the sloppier animation. The key creativity left Humongous before this game was made and it definitely shows that this is just a quick cash-in.\n\nWhether you're looking for nostalgia or a kids game, any of the other Putt-Putts are better.

reviewText: I knew in advance that this one wasn't made by the original team and by god does it show. The voices sound AWFUL. Considering they've never been great, either...\nThe dialogue has also been dumbed down to the point of being insulting, the puzzles are barely puzzles, there's so much reused scenes and animations... it's just a cash grab version of the older games with no effort put into it. Really, avoid this one. Not really even part of the series as far as I'm concerned.

reviewText: Putt Putt's voice is deeper, the voice acting is all around horrible (even for a Putt Putt game), and waiting for everyone to talk is painful. Save your time and money and don't play this game. Play a better one, Like Putt Putt Saves the Zoo.

reviewText: It's weird writting a negative review for a point-and-click adventure game aimed at a younger audience. Not because my standards for them are low, but because usually they are very interesting and fun despite the fact I am now an adult. However, Putt-Putt: Pep's Birthday Surprise is a lazy cash-in to a franchise after the original company (Humongous) was absorbed by Atari. Backgrounds are blatantly reused from older games, there's something horribly wrong with the audio (as in I can hear the microphone Putt-Putt's actor used during all of his lines), the voice-acting is stiff, and when I tried to give this game a second chance, the cut scenes kept glitching on me, something I didn't expect from this kind of game. In a game where you're just supposed to have fun and figure out what to do, it's somehow completely devoid of anything resembling fun.\n\nPutt-Putt was always my least favorite of the main Humongous Entertainment games, but they were good, with this one major exception. This game is terrible, I urge you to not cave in and try it for yourself.
